rename.to: Performance drop in the current master

body:
22f1b85515242c44d7e5a1be1e3960bdf6648b52 is the first bad commit
commit 22f1b85515242c44d7e5a1be1e3960bdf6648b52
Author: binary1248
Date:   Thu Dec 21 20:54:58 2017 +0100

    Added support for interfacing with joysticks via DirectInput when it is available.

This is weird. Have you tried to see whether this changes if you're using MinGW on Windows directly rather than cross-compiling? Also what controllers (if any) are connected? Does the behavior change with(out) controllers connected? What's your code?
@oomek Does SFML output anything to the console?

I know, but it gets even weirder. I'll try to explain the best I can.
This bug happens in the project I've recently started contributing to, the Attract Mode frontend for emulators. https://github.com/mickelson/attract
I cannot use MinGW because so far there is no known way to properly link to static MinGW libraries when AM is compiled. The weird part is that this bug only happens when I have an Ipac2 controller connected. Any other controller I own doesn't cause stuttering. What's more, it only affect 2 USB ports on my motherboard, other 2 ports work just fine. SFML does not output anything. I've tried linking to debug libraries.

There is many people using the configuration as I do, but since it's a very specific issue I'll try my best to help solving this mystery.
This doesn't sound like something that can be fixed in SFML code... More like a BIOS or driver issue.

I've checked the bios and drivers already and I have the latest. This bug started happening after your commit, so forgive me if I'll disagree here. It's worth to mention that ipac2 acts like a keyboard, but they probably used some multidevice trick internally to get rid of the max 6 key pressed limit.

I didn't imply you don't have the latest bios/drivers. Even the latest versions of things can still have bugs in them. The only difference that was introduced in that commit was the addition of DirectInput support. This is the same kind of implementation you will find in many other similar libraries such as SDL and GLFW. If you have the exact same issue using other DirectInput applications as well, then like I said, this is not something that can be resolved at the library level.
You may be right. I've tested it again and it appears that if any device is connected to the usb 3.0 port the stuttering occurs. I'll leave this open for now and do some more testing.
Since Attract Mode is using standard sfml input events is there any way to disable dinput from within app source?
Comment out [lines 206-209 in JoystickImpl.cpp](https://github.com/SFML/SFML/blob/master/src/SFML/Window/Win32/JoystickImpl.cpp#L206).

I've commented the lines and the stuttering is gone. Since AttractMode project’s owner keeps on insisting to stick to the official SFML release would you consider it as a good workaround to switch directinput to off by default and leave it to the developers to decide if they want to use?

The primary reason for implementing DirectInput was to fix a crash a lot of people were getting when using the legacy windows joystick API. I don't think we would be doing the majority of SFML users a favour by defaulting to only using the broken API over DirectInput.

If you can insert some debug `printf`s into JoystickImpl.cpp and provide some kind of trace with timing information, maybe we can build in some kind of workaround for such setups.
I’ll do it. Do you want the timestamps in every function?
